data.text:
We're interested in well-formed XML that satisfies the following conditions:

  • It has a root element "tasklist"
  • The root element has 3 "task" subelements
  • Each of the "task" subelements has an attribute named "name"
  • The values of the "name" attributes for the 3 tasks are "eat", "drink", and "play"
Select, from the choices below, the well-formed XML that meets the above requirements.
data.explanation:
Well-formed XML must follow these rules (along with others):

  • There must be exactly one top level element.
  • All opening tags must be closed.
  • All elements are properly nested i.e., there are no interleaved elements.
  • Attribute values must be enclosed in single or double quotes.

option.explanation: In well-formed XML, all opening tags, such as the three "task" tags, must be closed.
In well-formed XML, all attribute values, such as "eat", "drink" and "play", must be enclosed in quotes.
In well-formed XML, all opening tags, such as "tasklist", must be closed properly.
In well-formed XML, there must be exactly one top level element. In this choice, we have three top level elements.

data.explanation:
According to the DTD, an A element has within it one or more B subelements, and then a C element. Within the C element is zero or one B elements followed by exactly one D element. In terms of regular expressions, the tag sequences we can see are:

A (B /B)(B /B)* C (D /D | B /B D /D) /C /A.

Some text may appear between each B-/B pair and each D-/D pair, but text may not appear elsewhere.

option.text: A B /B B /B C B /B D /D /C /A
A B /B B /B B /B C D /D /C /A

option.explanation: Prior to the C, there must be one or more pairs of B /B tags.
Prior to the C there must be one or more pairs of B /B tags.
Within the C /C tag pair, there must be exactly one D /D pair.
Within the C /C tag pair, there must be exactly one D /D pair.

option.text: A B /B B /B C B /B B /B D /D /C /A
option.explanation: There is at most one B /B pair between the C tag and its matching /C tag.

option.text: A B /B B /B C B /B D /D D /D /C /A
option.explanation: Note that between the C tag and its matching /C tag there must be exactly one D /D pair.
Note that B /B pairs must precede, but not follow, the C /C pair.

option.text: A B /B B /B C D /D B /B /C /A
option.explanation: Between the C and /C tags, a B /B pair may precede, but not follow, the D /D pair.

option.text: A C B /B B /B D /D /C B /B /A
option.explanation: There is at most one B /B pair between the C tag and its matching /C tag. Also, B's cannot follow the /C tag.

option.text: A B /B B /B C B /B D /D /A
option.explanation: The /C tag that should match the C tag is missing

data.explanation: In the XML snippet, the info element has one address subelement and two phone subelements, in that order. Thus, in the DTD the list of components for INFO must include ADDR, ADDR*, ADDR+, or ADDR? followed by PHONE* or PHONE+. Interspersed with these may be any elements that are not required to appear-- that is, any components with a ? or *. Thus, we might also have components like NAME* or MANAGER? at any point in the list.

option.explanation: The ? says that there can be at most one phone.
The NAME component says that every INFO must have a NAME subelement.
The MANAGER component says that every INFO element has a MANAGER subelement.
The PHONE component, without a following * or +, says that there must be exactly one PHONE subelement.
This declaration requires the PHONE subelements to appear before the ADDR subelement.
This declaration requires an ADDR subelement to appear between two PHONE subelements.
This declaration says INFO has no nested subelements, just text.
This declaration requires every INFO element to have a MANAGER subelement.
The PHONE? component limits the number of PHONE subelements to 1.
The NAME+ component forces every INFO element to have at least one NAME subelement.

data.explanation:
The correct choices (i.e., the erroneous DTD snippets) are based on two rules:

  1. A #REQUIRED attribute must appear in every element.
  2. An attribute can have types CDATA, ID, or IDREF(S), but not #PCDATA.

The incorrect choices (i.e., the snippets that could appear in a DTD), are either optional attributes (#IMPLIED) or are required attributes of a proper type.

option.explanation: This is a correct choice, because a #REQUIRED attribute must appear with every element. In the example fragment of a document, we do not see the ssNo attribute in the EMP element.
This is a correct choice, because a #REQUIRED attribute must appear with every element. In the example fragment of a document, we do not see the owner attribute in the PHONE element.
This is a correct choice, because #PCDATA is not appropriate for the type of an attribute. It is used for the type of "leaf" text.
This is a correct choice, because a #REQUIRED attribute must appear with every element. In the example fragment of a document, we do not see the zip attribute in the ADDR element.
There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that EMP elements may have an ssNo attribute, but they are not required to.
There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that EMP elements may have an ssNo attribute, but they are not required to.
There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that PHONE elements may have an owner attribute, but they are not required to.
There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that PHONE elements may have an owner attribute, but they are not required to.
There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that ADDR elements may have a zip attribute, but they are not required to.
There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that EMP elements are required to have a name attribute, but the only example of such an element that we see does indeed have this attribute.
There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that EMP elements may have a name attribute, but the only example of such an element that we see does indeed have this attribute.

There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that EMP elements are required to have a name attribute, but the only example of such an element that we see does indeed have this attribute. The fact that it would be illogical for this attribute to be an IDREF is beside the point. It might be the name of the employee's manager, for example.
There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that PHONE elements are required to have a type attribute, but the only example of such an element that we see does indeed have this attribute.
There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that PHONE elements may have a type attribute, but the only example of such an element that we see does indeed have this attribute.

There is nothing wrong with this declaration. It says that PHONE elements are required to have a type attribute, but the only example of such an element that we see does indeed have this attribute. The fact that there is only one type listed in this IDREFS attribute is irrelevant --- an IDREFS attribute can have zero, one, or more values.

data.text:
Imagine that you are trying to extract CITY-LOCATED-IN-STATE(X, Y) relationships, where X represents the city and Y represents the state. Now we are given the following (nonsensical) document, which we use to both obtain features and extract relations: 

Palo Alto is in California. New York City is in New York. Palo Alto, California. Atlanta, Georgia. Smith, John. Atlanta is a city in Georgia. Shoe is a city in sock. Miami is within Florida.

Assume we first run the bootstrap algorithm and performed supervised learning on our expanded feature set to extract the relations. Assume we begin with the seed (Palo Alto, California). What is the expected F1 score of our algorithm? When calculating the F1 score, please keep in mind to eliminate duplicate entries. Please round your estimate to two decimal places (like 0.56). Finally, note that we are only trying to extract city-state relationships which exist in real life.
data.explanation:
Using the bootstrap + supervised learning method, we obtain the following new relations,

X is in Y (from "Palo Alto is in California")
X, Y (from "Palo Alto, California")
X is a city in Y (from "Atlanta is a city in Georgia")

With these relations, we extract the following:

Output:
(Palo Alto, California)
(New York City, New York)
(Atlanta, Georgia)
(Smith, John)
(Shoe, sock)

Looking at the passage, we can extract the true relationships of interest:

Gold:
(Palto Alto, California)
(New York City, New York)
(Atlanta, Georgia)
(Miami, Florida)

Recall = 3/4
Precision = 3/5

Using the formula for F1 score thus gives:

F1 = 2 * (9 / 20) * (20 / 27) = 18 / 27 = 2 / 3

option.explanation: Remember that the algorithm might run for multiple iterations
Remember that the algorithm might run for multiple iterations
